physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is set against a cream background, with blue and black panels. The main body of the kain panjang is decorated with stylised bats, winged animals, and tendrils. The left side of the kain panjang features two rows of opposing triangles decorated with rosettes and tendrils. There is a signature on the top-left of the batik kain panjang.
sgcool_label_text: Set against a cream background, the ‘body’ of this kain panjang is decorated with bats, symbolising good fortune in the Chinese tradition, birds with elaborate plumage, as well as flowering branches.  On the broad vertical panel (kepala), rows of interlocking triangles are filled with tiny rosettes and tendrils.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan Indonesia”.
